body: Same on WSL because git uses the agent to request credentials.
I am also troubled by this issue, and I would appreciate it if someone could solve it.

For anyone else following, you can get around this on a mac by running the tests with the GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true flag.

ie. ```GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true make test-sqlite```

Credit to @bohde for diagnosing it.
I think I saw this in `TestDumpRestore` and `TestGit`. Dismissing the notification appears to cause the fallback to be cached, which makes it difficult to catch every test that may cause this though.

issue.title: Avoid MacOS keychain dialog in integration tests

labels.name: modifies/go

repository.name: gitea
repository.description: Git with a cup of tea! Painless self-hosted all-in-one software development service, including Git hosting, code review, team collaboration, package registry and CI/CD

issue.body:
Mac's git installation ships with a system wide config that configures the credential helper `osxkeychain`, which will prompt the user with a dialog. 

```
$ git config list --system 
credential.helper=osxkeychain
```
By setting the environment variable [`GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true`](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config#ENVIRONMENT), Git will not load the system wide config, preventing the dialog from populating. 

Closes #26717

issue.body:
Backport #32813 by @bohde

Mac's git installation ships with a system wide config that configures the credential helper `osxkeychain`, which will prompt the user with a dialog. 

```
$ git config list --system 
credential.helper=osxkeychain
```
By setting the environment variable [`GIT_CONFIG_NOSYSTEM=true`](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-config#ENVIRONMENT), Git will not load the system wide config, preventing the dialog from populating. 

Closes #26717
